bboxes.raw_text:
CANTON. Miss. = A dynamite
blast destroyed a white-owned
grocery in a Negro neighbor-
hood. Eight sticks of dynamite
we're found in another store in the
neighborhood.


No injuries we're reported in
the explosion. FBI gents in
vestigated the blast in this cen
trail Mississippi town where civil
rights leaders claim a Negro
boycott of downtown merchants
. has been "85 percent effective"


George Raymond. Negro direc-
tor of the Council of Federated
Organizations activities in Can
ton, said the hull of the con-
crete block building was left
standing but the interior was
Extensively damaged"


All the windows we're blown
out, and the street was covered
with pieces of block, wood and
glass;" Raymond said. He said
much of the merchandise was
destroyed.


Raymond said the FBI and
sheriff's deputies removed eight
sticks of unexploded dynamite
from under the George Washing
ton Grocery after the Negro
owner, George Washington, saw
a cable leading under the building.

PICKENS, Miss. = Civil rights
workers reported the body of a
Negro youth who was a worker
for the Congress of Racial
Equality had been found in the
Big Black River near here.


The youth was identified as
Henry Orsby. IA, of New Or
leans, who was visiting his
grandparents in Pickens.


FBI agents and state officers
moved into the investigation. The
c Council of Federated Organi-
cations said he had not been
active in civil rights work in
Mississippi. although he was a
CORE worker in New Orleans.

A police car rear window was
broken by rocks Sunday by a
large group of Negro juveniles
at Ninth Avenue and Buckeye
Road.


Patrolman Earl Wrather and
reserve officer Ray Fields said
they stopped car for a traffic
violation at Ninth Avenue and
Buckeye.


Rocks we're thrown after Of
ficers told youth not to loi-
ter around the police acr. The
crowd was dispersed when addi-
tional officers arrived. There
were no arrests.

Four men were wounded dur
ing gun fight at the Trot Inn,
2432 E. Broadway Sunday night.


Injured when they scuffled near
some drums we're Johnnie Jones,
81. 1913 l n E. letters on, drum
mer at the tavern and Willie B.
Williams, 33. 1880 E. Adams,
ia, a customer, who had been
playing Jones' drums.


The men tussled and each one
pulled a hidden revolver and
fired at each other. Jones was
shot in the back and Williams
was struck in the left ankle.


Two patrons Ralph Flores, 81,
5l8 w. Fifth ST.. Tempe, and
George Johns on, 48. 200 E.
Broadway, we're injured. also.
Flores was wounded in the back
and Johns on's right foot was hit.

Emmett Race. newly appointed
manager of the Arizona State Fair
Coliseum, was greeted by more
than 400 civic leaders at well
come dinner, Fri, Sept. IL,
Thunderbird Room, Hotel West
ward Ho.


Mr.. Race, former manager of
the VIII Rogers Memorial Coli
scum, Fort Worth, Texas, said
the building would attract more
tourists and 1t would accommo-
date national travelling shows,
too. The state fair coliseum will
be finished in November 1865.


He invited all Arizonans to
assist the chamber of commerce
in bringing more conventions to
the state.

A charge of ars on was lodged
against Lilly Mae Archer, 27,
of 1901 E. Elwood.


Police said She admitted buy
ing a can of gasoline at a SER
vice station and using it in an
attempt to burn down a house
at 9O2 E. Monroe Sunday morn
ing after an argument with Rob-
ert Jack Banks, 26, one of two
tenants.

The report of President JoKanson's signing
a covenant restricting resale of some pro-
beyty he purchased should not be surprising.
The property Wus neUeY to be sold to Negroes
of Jews. This type Of agreement IS wtdety
used in different areas Of the country. 1t IS
often employed by real estate dealers to
keep community all Wlaite, free from Jews
or Negroes and any other groups considered
undesirable.


nv. johnson had not previously been a
staunch supporter Of civil rights until 1t
became politically Mise to do so. He has
clearly shooOn that he mill alter his position
sOken ne ceSS0Yy.


During the 1860 Democratic national con-
vention held in Los Angeles, his nomination
as the vice presidential candidate aOus not
supported by Negroes or the liberal faction
of the party. HIS record had little to indicate
he uas any different from other senators from
the South.


Mr.. johnson has made many YeUersals, and
no doubt more MILl be revealed

1t is incumbent upon every
person of every description to
contribute to his country's well
fare. George Washington

Harry E. Crawford, 1908 West
Sonora, Phoenix, was named
branch office representative of
the East Broadway office of Ari-
iona Public Service Company,
at 17l2 East Broadway. A 10
year veteran with APPS, Crawford
has served as a customer ser
viceman since 1861

awards banquet the bowling league w. H. Pat
Grand Canyon Temple 49, BPOEW
held Sunday at the lodge hall.


Sponsors trophies awarded Mr. Isiah Ward exalted
ruler and Mrs. Ruby Blackshear. daughter ruler.


Dorothy Clark league secretary presented the awards
